comments.body:
Notes from today, "EBS" testing only (block migration will need to be tested on Fedora tomorrow):

I set up three CentOS 6.3 machines: b-22, b-23, and b-24.  b-24 served iscsi targets, and b-22 and b-23 acted as libvirt / KVM nodes.  I did the following setup:

create target:
{code}
tgtadm --lld iscsi --op new --mode target --tid 1 -T iqn.2001-04.com.example:disk1.b24.eucalyptus-systems.com
{code}

back it with an lvm volume:
{code}
lvcreate vg01 -n disk1 -L 5G
tgtadm --lld iscsi --op new --mode logicalunit --tid 1 --lun 1 -b /dev/mapper/vg01-disk1
{code}

export it:
{code}
tgtadm --lld iscsi --op bind --mode target --tid 1 -I 10.101.1.23
tgtadm --lld iscsi --op bind --mode target --tid 1 -I 10.101.1.22
{code}

tweak iptables:
{code}
iptables -I INPUT 4 --proto tcp --dport 3260 -j ACCEPT
{code}

discover it from KVM node:
{code}
# iscsiadm --mode discovery --type sendtargets --portal 10.101.1.24
10.101.1.24:3260,1 iqn.2001-04.com.example:disk1.b24.eucalyptus-systems.com
{code}

login from KVM node:
{code}
# iscsiadm --mode node --targetname iqn.2001-04.com.example:disk1.b24.eucalyptus-systems.com --portal 10.101.1.24:3260 --login
Logging in to [iface: default, target: iqn.2001-04.com.example:disk1.b24.eucalyptus-systems.com, portal: 10.101.1.24,3260] (multiple)
Login to [iface: default, target: iqn.2001-04.com.example:disk1.b24.eucalyptus-systems.com, portal: 10.101.1.24,3260] successful.
{code}

get device name (the way that connect_iscsitarget.pl does):
{code}
# iscsiadm -m session -P 3 | awk '/Attached scsi disk/ { print $4 }'
sdc
{code}

*NOTE*: I had to connect to iscsi target from *both* b-22 and b-23, and the device had to be the same (/dev/sdc),  This would work much better if we referenced /dev/disk/by-path/ (example entry:  ip-10.101.1.24:3260-iscsi-iqn.2001-04.com.example:disk1.b24.eucalyptus-systems.com-lun-1 ) as you then do not have to care about the sd* name.  That means a change to tools/connect_iscsitarget.pl, which would simplify that script, but we'd need to ensure that it doesn't break other distros.

Moving on...

dump bfebs image into the disk:
{code}
wget -nd http://mirror.qa.eucalyptus-systems.com/bfebs-image/bfebs.img
cat bfebs.img >/dev/sdc
{code}

(yes I could have done that with a single curl command.  whatever)

Notes about setting up libvirt:
* modprobe kvm_intel
* yum install qemu-kvm
* due to order of ops, /dev/kvm may have wrong group assignment (if module is loaded before udev rule is installed)
* maybe running virsh capabilities is needed?
* I didn't have bridged networking set up yet, so first tried NAT with virbr0

libvirt.xml:
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<domain type="kvm">
  <name>frobinator</name>
  <description>Eucalyptus frobinator</description>
  <os>
    <type>hvm</type>
  </os>
  <features>
    <acpi/>
  </features>
  <clock offset="localtime"/>
  <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff>
  <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot>
  <on_crash>destroy</on_crash>
  <vcpu>1</vcpu>
  <memory>2097152</memory>
  <devices>
    <disk device="disk" type="block">
      <driver name='qemu' type='raw' cache="none"/>
      <source dev="/dev/sdc"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
    <interface type="bridge">
      <source bridge="virbr0"/>
      <mac address="D0:0D:5A:79:89:73"/>
      <model type="e1000"/>
    </interface>
    <serial type="file">
      <source path="/tmp/foobar-console.log"/>
      <target port="1"/>
    </serial>
    <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' keymap='en-us' listen='0.0.0.0'/>
  </devices>
</domain>
{code}

After running "virsh create libvirt.xml", I logged in via VNC (because the VM was NAT'ed), and ssh-tunnelled to b-24, so that I could test whether tcp connections survived (spoiler: they didn't).  then ran the migrate command:

{code}
virsh migrate --live frobinator qemu+ssh://b-22.devtest.eucalyptus-systems.com/system
{code}

First error:
error: Unsafe migration: Migration may lead to data corruption if disks use cache != none

This resulted in the addition of this line in the xml:

{code:xml}
      <driver name='qemu' type='raw' cache="none"/>
{code}

Second error:
error: unable to connect to server at 'b-22.devtest.eucalyptus-systems.com:49152': No route to host

port 49152 is not a well-known port; it's a random port.  So I added an iptables rule to b-22:

{code}
iptables -I INPUT 6 --proto tcp --source b-23.devtest.eucalyptus-systems.com -j ACCEPT
{code}

After that, the migration worked.  Note that it prompts for the root password, so having ssh keys (or something equivalent) set up is a must.

And as mentioned, I had a simple ssh connection open during the migrate, and it dropped.  It might be more interesting to try something like a web server with requests coming in, to see how many have errors.

I started my testing of non-shared-storage migration by looking at this document:

http://wiki.qemu.org/Features/LiveBlockMigration

I found the document a little confusing, because the examples were very focused on using iscsi devices.  So I went through setting up tgtd and iscsid on my two Fedora machines, only to tear them back down again when I realized how things really worked.  The steps that seemed to be necessary:

* Allow arbitrary network connections between the two hosts (same as was required in the shared storage test)
* set up ssh keys between the hosts
* grab an image (I used http://mirror.qa.eucalyptus-systems.com/bfebs-image/bfebs.img again... didn't care about the separate kernel / ramdisk for this exercise)
* Create a libvirt.xml file:

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<domain type="kvm">
  <name>frobinator</name>
  <description>Eucalyptus frobinator</description>
  <os>
    <type>hvm</type>
  </os>
  <features>
    <acpi/>
  </features>
  <clock offset="localtime"/>
  <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff>
  <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot>
  <on_crash>destroy</on_crash>
  <vcpu>1</vcpu>
  <memory>2097152</memory>
  <devices>
    <disk device="disk" type="file">
      <driver name='qemu' type='raw' cache="none"/>
      <source file="/var/tmp/bfebs.img"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
    <interface type="bridge">
      <source bridge="virbr0"/>
      <mac address="D0:0D:5A:79:99:73"/>
      <model type="e1000"/>
    </interface>
    <serial type="file">
      <source path="/tmp/foobar-console.log"/>
      <target port="1"/>
    </serial>
    <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' keymap='en-us' listen='0.0.0.0'/>
  </devices>
</domain>
{code}

* launch it:  {code}virsh create libvirt.xml{code}
* log in and run something on it
* migrate:  {code}virsh migrate --live frobinator --copy-storage-all qemu+ssh://b-26.devtest.eucalyptus-systems.com/system{code}

Note that there is also a "copy-storage-inc" option to copy only the non-shared portion of images with the same base.  I wonder if we could do something like cache an EMI in the same location on both NCs, so that we get the performance of a local file, but then can do an incremental migration instead of a full image migration.

The whole set of migration flags, from the API reference:

{noformat}
          VIR_MIGRATE_LIVE      Do not pause the VM during migration
          VIR_MIGRATE_PEER2PEER Direct connection between source & destination hosts
          VIR_MIGRATE_TUNNELLED Tunnel migration data over the libvirt RPC channel
          VIR_MIGRATE_PERSIST_DEST If the migration is successful, persist the domain
                                   on the destination host.
          VIR_MIGRATE_UNDEFINE_SOURCE If the migration is successful, undefine the
                                      domain on the source host.
          VIR_MIGRATE_CHANGE_PROTECTION Protect against domain configuration
                                        changes during the migration process (set
                                        automatically when supported).
          VIR_MIGRATE_UNSAFE    Force migration even if it is considered unsafe.
{noformat}

The libvirt API only provides a single step for migration via the public API.  Internally, it looks like there's a sequence of calls.  The latest code says:

{noformat}
 * Sequence v3:
 *
 *  Src: Begin
 *        - Generate XML to pass to dst
 *        - Generate optional cookie to pass to dst
 *
 *  Dst: Prepare
 *        - Get ready to accept incoming VM
 *        - Generate optional cookie to pass to src
 *
 *  Src: Perform
 *        - Start migration and wait for send completion
 *        - Generate optional cookie to pass to dst
 *
 *  Dst: Finish
 *        - Wait for recv completion and check status
 *        - Kill off VM if failed, resume if success
 *        - Generate optional cookie to pass to src
 *
 *  Src: Confirm
 *        - Kill off VM if success, resume if failed
 *
{noformat}

Hooks are hypervisor specific:
libvirt.org/hooks.html

The hook script is called at the "begin" step of the migrate, and the domain xml can be manipulated at that time:

* /etc/libvirt/hooks/qemu guest_name migrate begin -

Then, before QEMU process is spawned, the hooks for the two operations ("prepare" and "start") called for domain start are executed on destination host:

* /etc/libvirt/hooks/qemu guest_name prepare begin -

The above hook is before libvirt performs any resource labeling, and the hook can allocate resources not managed by libvirt such as DRBD or missing bridges.

* /etc/libvirt/hooks/qemu guest_name start begin -

The above hook occurs after libvirt has finished labeling all resources, but has not yet started the guest.

EL 6 currently ships libvirt 0.9.10, which did *not* include the migrate hook in the upstream release, but this was added as a patch for https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=795127 and released as part of http://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2012-0748.html

Notable constraint which would be worth preserving in our own documentation of migration:  "Same CPUs, or better said CPUs have to be from the same vendor and CPU flags on the destination host must be superset of CPU flags on source."   It may seem like an obvious requirement, but this will be important if customers deploy clouds with heterogeneous NCs. It may limit their ability to perform maintenance if the only free slots are on older CPUs.

Paused VMs seems to support a fairly broad set of customizations, including attaching and detaching disks and other edits to the VM definition.  Snapshotting a paused VM should work, so long as all attached disk devices support it.  I just tried to test a snapshot after a number of disk attach / detach events, though, and my virsh session appears to be just hanging.

It appears I was wrong about EL6 lacking support for the non-shared storage case:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=677220

This would seem to indicate that the code was in 6.1

UPDATE: I've done more tests on this.  In short:

Good news: live migration with non-shared storage on CentOS 6.3 works fine in my tests. In fact, when I retested using a direct network connection (i.e., no manual routing changes required), I was able to keep an ssh connection running through the duration of the migration.

Bad news: it occurred to me that [~decker] was onto something when outlining the various use cases, in particular  calling out the case where a standard instance had EBS volumes attached, meaning both non-shared and shared storage.  So I tested and verified that {{--copy-storage-all}} cannot differentiate between the two, and it will happily block copy an iscsi volume over itself.  I suspect that we'd actually be better off coming up with a mechanism to copy a snapshot of the non-shared disks and then use {{--copy-storage-inc}} to do an incremental copy.  I'm still looking into the details of how "increments" are represented here. I suspect that this would imply the use of qcow images.

I've created two VMs. First backed by remote drive and second backed by local file. First VM was involved in the shared drive migration and second VM was used for non-shared drive migration. Both VMs had remote disks attached. I've loaded VMs with constant large files copying operation between local drive and attached remote drive(s). After each copy operation MD5 file sum was calculated. VMs was also loaded with serving HTTP file download requests. While those VMs ware doing those operation they were constantly moved back and forth between host. I was able to perform system update on migrating systems. Hosted boxes were running several VMs at the same time.
I've moved systems 300+ times between host without noticing any file corruptions.

Aborted non-shared storage migration with attached iscsi drive(s) could lead to corruption of VMs file system.
Simplest way to reproduce this is to load system with some heavy memory usage, for instance run a script that create and clean up few large hashes. Migration that is executed at the same time can't catch up with changing memory and hangs for a long time. If this migration is interrupted this could lead to corrupted file on migrated VM.

You don't have to be on the source box in order to start migration. The --connect option can be used. For example, this call: 'virsh --connect qemu+ssh://192.168.51.125/system migrate --live test qemu+ssh://192.168.51.157/system' initiates migration from 192.168.51.125 to 192.168.51.157.

I've created two Ubuntu images. Both with 2G RAM and 2G drive. First images had local 1G swap disc and two 5G iscsi disks attached. Both instances were migrated back and forth between two boxes hundreds of time. I have not seen any corrupted disks cases this time (I did not interrupt migrations). Without any load on VM it is migrated in about 2 minutes. With memory and IO load migration takes about 8 to 10 minutes for the same VM.
